page.title: 09Local History(Great Ponton)
page.content: The original settlement may date from Roman times , suggested by numerous finds relating to this period and the discovery of a mosaic pavement in field OS8763 . There is evidence in Greens 'Lincolnshire Towns and Villages' that William the Conqueror,himself,held land here. The village has an uncommon weather vane in the shape of a fiddle.The story goes that a travelling musician who ,on the occasions he passed through Great Ponton,was always well treated.He eventually went to America, made a fortune and returning to England gave a golden fiddle in thanks for their good fellowship when he was poor.This was copied and placed as a weather vane on the church. It is reported that a monks' escape tunnel still exists between the vicarage and Mill House( 1 mile long).
